reviewText: I am absolutely addicted to this series. The writing is so rich! I have to applaud the writers who took the books and turned them into this layered and quite involving series. I am viewing Season 2 now and wondering how long before I'll be able to see Season Three released on DVD.

You will weep, you will vibrate with love for this beautiful wonderful series dealing with people that you wish you could live with and know.  I have Lark Rise  To Candleford 1 and 2 and eagerly await as many seasons as they make. I can honestly say that I feel as close to these characters in this series as I do my own relatives. The settings, costumes and scenery plus an absolutely perfect cast make this the most satisfying hours I have ever spent watching a DVD.  I could not stop thinking of the love, loyalty, heartbreak, hardships,and perseverence of these dear persons as they struggle with temptations, inner turmoil, ecstatic love and doubts as they prove over and over how much they trust and love one another and their strength and loyalty to their own beliefs and feelings.
This is not a sweet sugar coated series.  I actually flinched in some parts as reality seemed too harsh to be bearable, yet the joys and triumphs only prove that,yes, is as it was supposed to be.  It is an absolute masterpiece of how stories should be filmed and told...brought to us by a skillful and loving group of actors, writer, directors and producers who must feel and love their accomplishment with this as we feel and love their films..Thank you for such love everyone...

Fast becoming my favorite show.  I thought the first few episodes were good, but the more I watched, the more I loved it.  I couldn't stop watching.  Thought provoking, entertaining.  You'll laugh & cry & think about it after it's done.  Very well done with outstanding acting.  A must, must watch.

I will not repeat much of what has already been written by others. The "Christmas Special" episode could become as essential an annual viewing as Dickens' "Christmas Carol." or "The Snowman." It is a complete story in itself and does not have its genesis in earlier episodes and does not carry the story forward in subsequent ones. So watching this episode is satisfying in that it has a beginning, a middle and an end. You can then move on to the continuing story from the events in the first season. The new maid, Minnie (Ruby Bentall) may strike you as a bit too muddled and accident prone to be true in the early episodes, but her back story emerges gradually through the series and she develops into an interesting character, and we learn why Dorcas employed her rather any one of a hundred less problematic girls available to her. Twister is revealed as not just a comical figure but that he has a mean streak in him at times. Laura will melt the hardest heart, and I defy anyone not to weep at what I consider is her strongest scene in the whole series, and that is from an actress who shines in every scene in which she appears. I am watching season three at the moment and it is every bit as good as the first two. You have some wonderful treats to come.

What else can I say, but that I absolutely love this BBC period drama series!!  (I'm must admit that I'm an avid admirer of most period/historical/costume dramas; and who else makes them better but the BBC?!)

I started watching this series during the time the 1st season was airing in the UK. I fell in love with the characters, beautiful backdrop, and quaint country life of long ago.  I couldn't wait to share this lovely series with my family, so I ended up pre-ordering the 1st season off of Amazon UK.  I also ended up doing the same for season 2- not knowing if or when it would come to the states.  Thankfully,  PBS has since included this gem of a show on it's lineup!  ..I'm just wondering if we'll have to wait as long for season 3 to air, as we did for the last two.  In fact, it wasn't until season 2 had ended in the UK, that they finally started showing season 1.  ..Better late than never I guess =o)

  Anyway, you might recognize some of the shows main characters.  As was noted by another reviewer; Dorcas Lane is played by none other than Julia Sawalha, who is quite the period drama veteran (most recently she also had a starring role in "Cranford"- another favorite of mine)!!  Then there's Brendan Coyle (Robert Timmins) whom you might remember as Nicholas Higgins in Elizabeth Gaskell's "North & South" (BBC).  Laura's mother Emma, is played by Claudie Blakley, who was Charlotte Lucas in the '05 "Pride & Prejudice", and maid Martha in "Cranford".

 Now to my review..  (I watched all but the first episode.)  Although a few of the characters from the first season are missing (notably "Sir Timothy"), and some new ones introduced- it seems to flow well, and compliment the 1st season nicely.

  I adore Thomas Brown and Miss Ellison; they are quite the pair!  I'm very  glad that we're able to watch their relationship blossom and come to fruition in this new season!

One of the new characters- Minnie the maid (played by Ruby Bentall; who also appears in "The Courageous Heart of Irena Sendler", and "Lost in Austen")- takes some getting used to though.  Even through all her childish mistakes, you can see the character learn and grow; and by the end of the season, she is likeable.

I think perhaps my favorite new character (unfortunately only a guest-star for 3 episodes), was Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty; who appears in the "Return to Cranford" special).  You couldn't help but be smitten with him-- right along with Laura.  This is her first taste of love; and as most "first loves" go, they don't last as long as one might hope (but still leave a lasting impression nonetheless).  ..I'm rooting for a reappearance of him in the 3'd season, but I don't see anything mentioned on his IMDB page.

I was also glad to see that Alf (John Dagleish.. a dead ringer for a young Sylvester Stallone) was able to come into his own in this season; and develop feelings for someone other than Laura (even if the girl wasn't that deserving).  And through it all he continues to be the pillar of strength, and competent provider for his younger siblings- just as he was in the 1st season!

Finally, who can forget the Turrill's?!  You can't help but laugh and shake your head at the funny things Twister does, and commiserate at times with Queenie.  They're a bit of an odd couple; but they make it work--most comically!  (And you'll find out a little revelation regarding their relationship in this season.)

As I mentioned earlier, there is a season 3 (so breathe a sigh of relief).  The first episode aired Jan. 10th in the UK!  ..If the season is as long as season 2 (12 ep's), then it should be available for pre-order this spring (April or May) on Amazon.uk!!  Meanwhile I'll be feverishly checking the IMDB page, and the PBS listings (once season 2 is finished replaying; it's about half over at the moment) to see when it will air in the US!  If not, I can always order it off of Amazon UK again.  If you plan on ordering from the UK, just be sure your dvd player is Region free, or PAL (region 2) compatible.  I have an inexpensive GPX dvd player (# D1816SIL) that I purchased 3 years ago, and they play fine!

My only complaint about the series, is that it doesn't have longer seasons (season 1 had only ten, and season 2- twelve episodes).  It seems like you're waiting forever (about a year) for the next season!  But I guess that can't be helped.  ..Let's just hope that there will be a season 4!!

  Oh, if you're looking for something a bit comparable from the US, please check out "Christy" (a short lived series starring Kelly Martin and Tyne Daly), or "Dr. Quinn Medicine Woman" (Jane Seymour, & Joe Lando).  Or the "Road To Avonlea" series from Canada!

Lark Rise to Candleford: The Complete Season One is a charming series that tackles myriad themes, and is adapted from Flora Thompson's semi-autobiographical novel. In the first season, young Laura Timmins (Olivis Hallinan) leaves her village of Lark Rise to work as an assistant to the postmistress in Candleford, Dorcas Lane (Julia Sawalha who was also brilliant in her role as Lydia Bennet in Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E, 1996)). Through the course of the first season, Laura discovers that she enjoys living in the more affluent town of Candleford, and experiences the pangs of adolescence, including romantic entanglements. Dorcas Lane, the kind-hearted and sensible postmistress also goes through some pangs of her own, largely to do with her friendship with squire, Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) who is married to the beautiful and composed Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant). In the first season, viewers got to see the themes of marital strife, conflicts between the upper and lower classes, romantic entanglements, and other issues played out. By the second season, both Sir Timothy and Lady Adelaide have moved to London, but there is still plenty of drama in Dorcas' life with the arrival of James Dowland (Jason Merrells), a former inhabitant of Lark Rise, a local boy who has done well in life. Being a self-made and wealthy man, James settles in Candleford, though he reacquaints himself with the residents of Lark Rise, especially Queenie Turrill (Linda Bassett) who used to take care of him as a young boy. James opens a fashionable hotel in Candleford, and tries to 'improve' the lives of the Lark Rise residents with mixed results. There is also a strong chemistry between James and Dorcas, though their relationship flounders between attraction and rivalry/conflict. Laura seems more mature and wiser, having learned a couple of enlightening things about the pitfalls of romance, and is taking on more responsibilities at the post office. But then, a young clockmaker, Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty) comes to town, and Laura finds herself attracted to Fisher, though he seems oblivious to her charms, initially. Laura's parents, Robert and Emma Timmins (Brendan Coyle & Claudie Blakley) who have always been a very close and loving couple find themselves facing some marital strife in their marriage, and this second season takes an intimate look at their dynamics as a couple. There is also plenty of drama amongst the other inhabitants of Lark Rise & Candleford - the sisters Pearl and Ruby Pratt (Matilda Ziegler, Victoria Hamilton) who have a dressmaking/drapery store continue to pry into others' affairs whilst dealing with their own emotional dramas. Postman Thomas Brown's (Mark Heap)romantic (mis)adventures continue, and many more. This is truly a gem of a series, and I am hopelessly addicted to it. Each episode is well-crafted and credibly acted, drawing viewers into the lives of these mostly endearing & flawed characters, and making one feel at home in both Lark Rise and Candleford. For those who love period dramas, there's some wonderful productions (these are some of my favorites) to check out: Cranford: The Collection (Cranford / Return to Cranford) Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E, 1996) Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980) Daniel Deronda Anne of Green Gables Trilogy Box Set Road to Avonlea Season 1 and others in the series Wives and Daughters The Buccaneers

Such places as Lark Rise and Candleford are towns most of us can only dream of living in.  Darling Laura Timmins (Olivia Hallinan), oldest child of a Lark Rise family, is sent off to Candleford to learn the trade of postmistress. That all began in Series One which I recommend you view first. See my review.  I ordered my copy of this DVD set as soon as I saw it was available.

English country life could never have been as poetic, pictorial, and enchanting as this dramatization of the lives of those living in and around the two 1880's towns of Lark Rise and Candleford. Even the DVD's music puts a sanguine sugarcoating on the period. All of this is to the delight of the viewer of this masterfully done TV series sure to endear any North American who has a tender video heart toward Victorian Britain. Perhaps, consider it a British mutation of "Little House on the Prairie" or "The Waltons."

Filmed locations and sets are to-die-for your next vacation spot. Costumes to dazzle, delight, and disgust, depending upon the event. Every emotion you have ever felt in your past will be repeated sometime throughout this English town saga. The adapted books by Flora Thompson have never been read by this reviewer, but I can't imagine them being as fine as this TV series (and I'm a book lover). A superb British cast has perfected this story.

I was able to watch this thanks to my friend who lives in the UK (it hasn't been released in the US yet). I am so glad that the BBC has okayed a third season (to be telecast in 2010), and I hope the second season of this DVD will be made available for viewers in the US soon.
Love BBC,! They do such a great job on dramas and period pieces. Historical dramas are amazing!
i really like this show wish it was more than two seasons.
I love this series.  To me it's safe tv.
Takes you to a time gone by, yet with all the same foibles, joys, worries, etc. Very well done.
I loved it just as much as the first season!!

I have watched this series a couple of times and I know I will watch it again.  There are scenes that made me laugh and scenes that made me cry.  A couple of the actors were also characters in Downton Abbey and Poldark.  This is a good quality series with quality actors and I loved visiting and revisiting them.
We love watching this family friendly show with our 10 year old daughter!
Season 2 continues the quality and plot lines

We have binge watched this series as an antidote to the political news. Very enjoyable; lovely countryside and village scenes, good acting and story lines. Why is it the British can make these kinds of series so much better than we? Recognizable actors from Downton Abbey, Poldark, Call the Midwife and other great English shows.
I just love all the storylines. Piece series are very knowledgeable. Love the way the classy ladies dress. Wish I was from that era.

Pleasant, easy-going series highlighting all the character's various lives and experiences. It's slow-paced and quaint but enjoyable. Laura is actually my least-favorite character, followed by Thomas, but mostly because of the acting. Other than that it's a great, easy show to watch.
very enjoyabl well written
I enjoyed every episodes

It is a show that is clean.family oriented the violence is menial I love it .it teaches life lessons.
Might be my favorite series yet.  Teaches good lessons and has a great cast.  I adored "Twister" and "Queenie!"  wish it had more seasons
Very good show! Characters are interesting and show is captivating.

The show fills that niche that seems to have been empty for too long - wholesome television where the characters are developed beyond their looks and there's a moral to the story.  It is a refreshing break from the tendencies of today's viewing opportunities.
Love this series! Simple times, no violence, very family friendly. Beautiful scenery and just a happy show to watch.
Lovely rural British saga... Thoroughly enjoyed it!
Intriguing
A quaint show with great humor and acting. Loved it.

If you want action and adventure this might not be for you. But my action loving husband even got into a few episodes. But if you were a Downton Abby fan you will have a hard time not being watching this show.
Love this series. Refreshing writing. Small town drama tastefully done.

Sometimes I think this is even better than Downton Abbey even though this has a much "sweeter" character to it.  Really fantastic stuff if you long for the England depicted in many of Ralph Vaughn-William's musical compositions.

They should have started off every episode with "The Lark Ascending" IMHO.  I have never seen anything that captures the flavor of what I imagine rural England to have been like in the 19th century.  I doubt if it was quite this idyllic but allow me my fantasies.

Every season of Lark Rise to Candleford is essential viewing for all Anglophiles.  Great acting, stunning cinematography and a really great story line throughout.

I thank Amazon for making Season 4 available on Prime Streaming Video!
A wonderful clean and wholesome show.
I love this series.  It takes you back to a time when things were much simpler.
Finished two seasons.  Looking forward to the next season. Very, very enjoyable.
Excellent miniseries.  Very enjoyable.

A very delightful series of life in rural England in 1895 through the eyes of a young girl from a tiny hamlet working in a pretentious town post office. Colorful characters abound and weave through her life a patchwork of social issues. Highly recommended for those who enjoy historically based lighthearted drama.
We love these characters.
I have viewed this series twice now and am so sad there are not more than 3 seasons.

This is but a peak into small town Irish/English culture in days long ago.  The scenery is beautiful, the characters are delightful, some bawdy, meddling........everything that goes only today, but with an old fashioned decency that we've pretty thrown to the wind.
Interesting characters and fresh look at times gone by. Strong women and dependable men living together as a community while their world is changing from old to modern
This is a charming story of a small hamlet and larger nearby town and the citizens of each.  It takes place in the late 1800s and the acting and story line are really good.
My wife loves this show!
Addicting....
Sweet easy watch. Characters with humility, very charming.

great characters and i love how there is closure at the end of every episode

I love this series. The episode abut the ghost did seems a bit out of character, but it was still good.
The characters are so believable

I love this series about Britain in the 1800s. The acting is outstanding; the story lines interesting and characters are fully developed with a focus on several each episode. Great, clean entertainment.
This series is good clean family fare.  It is well written and acted.
Wish there were more
It's a nice period piece.
I could not adore this series more! It's a clean fun comedy with plenty of sentimental moments to balance it out! It's beautifully crafted!
I love this show!!
A very sweet and tender story
Great show!  A real glimpse into the past!
Love the shoe

Second season is continuing to develop the characters in an entertaining, however, somewhat unbelievable, at times, way. All in all, it's a good little series for light entertainment that is wholesome for the whole family to watch. The scenery and costumes are lovely.
This is such a good series for the entire family to watch together. I love the story line and enjoyed each episode. I highly recommend this series.
Series does follow books but jumps around the chapters. Many of the actors are in the new series: The Crown.
A wonderful series!  I enjoyed every moment of it!
Exceptionally well done series.
What a lovely Program
Well done period show. Characters are engaging and likeable, but some not believable. Plots are simplistic with a lot of dancing,but pleasant nonetheless.
The best. Love the depth of character and beautiful acting.
It was pretty good but at times to simplistic.

I've recommended this series to everyone I know. This is my 2nd time watching the series. I wish it would have aired on PBS. I only found out about it because of "Since you watched Pride and Prejudice Amazon Recommends Larkrise to Candleford". I wish it were longer than 4 seasons!

I love it that this series is based on a set of characters and the issues and challenges they face in life. How they deal with their challenges and weaknesses, how they interact, how they love, how they sometimes hurt each other and so on. I love how this is not the standard fare of someone being killed followed by a lot of gratuitous violence and mayhem intermingled with politically correct messaging. 10 stars to the producers!

Watching the characters develop and seeing familiar faces from other BBC series I have enjoyed. Sad to say I have become disenchanted with Dorcas Lane. She seems to be a very self-satisfied know it all. That is a credit to the producers however as it gives the characters authenticity. We all have faults and the village and hamlet work because people are accepting of one another. A lesson for us today.
I like the season 3 and 4 a lot.

I think this may become my all time favorite show. With everything going on in the world these days, it"s nice to stick my head in the sand and watch this show. It's pleasant, heartwarming and has a wide array of charming characters.
Such a nice series. Beautifully done!
Enjoyed it immensely. Waiting for the sequel.

These series is one of the best shows we have seen in a long time. The characters are so entertaining and the storyline is always interesting. It's so refreshing to watch an episode with no profanity or inappropriate nudity. We love it!!!

Great acting by fine cast.  The script is tight and great on detail.  Human emotions are well understood and the characters become people you really care about.  About half way through the seasons and don't want it to end ever.
Love this show!!!
Love this era and love how the characters evolve

Loved it very much...

Love this series.
Love this show!!!

Pleasant to watch with its mild humor and drama. A little romance doesn't hurt either. I would enjoying seeing more television like this.
Cant say why but I luv this series. I love getting entwined in their lives and am happy to see a show with characters that actually have goods morals for a change.
Wonderfully written story of long ago. A must watch!

Very enjoyable family series.

Loved this series.  Wish that it had not been canceled!

I eagerly await the moment when I can sit down and watch the next episode.  I thoroughly enjoy being able to watch a wholesome program that does not rely on violence and foul language as its attraction but rather its lessons on being kind and understanding human beings to one another.
Love everything about it!

Enjoying the 3rd season currently, i like all the characters & the roles they play, they do so well it feels like im there in that day & time. Very good story lines about life back then, also love the english countryside!!
Love the characters! True to life and good humor. Holds my interest.
great show!!!

One of the most excellent series I've ever watched ! Wonderful characters and diverse stories within stories.
Best of all ? It's clean G rated!

This has become our favorite BBC series.  We are now on season four and dread finding out when this series ends.  Without a doubt, it is one of the best loved and best overall series we have ever watched.  Brilliant writing, superb acting and breathtaking cinematography.  In an era of American television in which a hit show must contain graphic violence, explicit sex or vulgarity to succeed its nice to find something that contains none of them.  American television could learn this from the BBC, but I hold little hope that it will.

I love being caught up in the residents' lives of both Lark Rise and Candleford. To call it a "soap opera" shouldn't diminish the quality of the programs, but that's how the stories play out. The characters' lives are intertwined with ongoing plots as well as fresh stories in each episode. It's wonderful!
Can't stop watching
Excellent acting and fascinating story.
Nice
Very good.
Wonderful, fully developed characters. So many of Britain's fine actors  pass through Lark Rise and Candleford. A real pleasure to watch.
Wonderful, inspiring, entertainment.
Very pleasant series about two "classes" of people in England years ago.
Lovely, well acted and good family entertainment.  Wholesome and beautiful
Beautifully done and fun to watch.
the working "man's" version of Downton Abbey
Best show ever. Such a classic. Season 2 is definitely my favorite, but they are all good.
I really liked this show I hope they make more!
I lived it . I was so upset it ended with season 4 episode 6.
a bit maudlin but fabulous acting and cosutmes, sweet little vinettes on coloquial life.
I Love all the characters on this series.  They make me want to live in Candleford!
I have loved this series since the first episode!  It's warm and caring but showers the good and not so good in people.  Simple folk with lots of heart.
Excellent.

What a great series. The characters were so rich and fun. Wish it was still running.
Sweet!

This series is very well done! It's so refreshing to watch something without violence or a car chase. Plus great costumes and sets. We also enjoy seeing actors and actresses from Downton Abby, Call the Midwife and Harry Potter in new roles.
Another BBC classic! Terrific!

What a delightful show; my preteen daughter and I love to watch it together.  The character development is excellent, and it's intriguing and family-friendly at the same time.  I highly, highly recommend this show.

I love this series. It's perfect for family viewing. Especially if you have young girls in your family with a literary bent. There's romance, morality, and a healthy dose of Feminism and Liberalism. Plus, gorgeous Victorian costumes and pretty good acting.
Love this show. So relaxing

Season 2 of Lark Rise to Candleford is great just like seasons 1 and 3.  4 because of the loss of Fergus Drysdale as Laura's father combined with the condensed number of episodes with a finale that compressed so much that could have been spread across the 6 episodes available (instead of some of the worst episodes of the show), Season 5 is less but still must be watched to see how they wrap up the storyline.  Overall the show is one of the best stories I've watched in a long time.  The story of the poor and working class in mid 1800's England is heart warming.  Nothing in these shows that you have to send your children away from, or would offend anyone.  Simple good old story telling of how the bonds of love and friendship held together these old communities that worked so hard and faced so many adversities yet managed to prevail.  I was touched by many, amused, and generally entertained by a show I simply wish had gone on for many more seasons.  But what there is of it is a great watch, so soak it up because you'll find little to compare.  I myself see it as a combination of Anne of Green Gables, Downton Abbey and a touch of Poldark.  Loved it.

I am in the middle of the second season, and I feel that I live amid all the familiar characters who live in Park Rise and Candleford.  They are families, neighbors, some come and go, some come and stay, most are hard-working laborers, some shop keepers and small business owners.  They are so believable that it is sometimes difficult to realize that these episodes are simply imagined by a talented writer.  Every evening I look forward to the antics of the people of these two towns.  I can highly recommend this series of stories of life and love and adventure, happiness and sadness . . . . . life.

This is a nice Family Series similar to Little House on the Prarie (not as sappy) or the Waltons. It takes place in Ireland probably 1800's. It is the story of several farm families living in the country (renting from rich land owners); and their interaction with those living in town. The young girl, Laura, leaves her family to work for her aunt who runs the post office in town. She enjoys it a little too much (as far as her mother is concerned) who actually sent her away, as she had too many children to care for. Laura's father is a bit of a rebel. Always ready to take on the establishment- religious or otherwise. If you want a nice show without cursing and good morale values you will enjoy this one.

The hamlet and town are supposed to be 8 miles apart.  That's 16 miles over and back.  Yet characters regularly go back and forth as if their were some high speed computer train.

Picturesque series with many familiar faces including Brendan Coyle (Downton Abbey 's Mr. Bates) among the cast.
The episodes take place in the late 19th century in two small neighboring English country villages.  Lark Rise is rustic home to the working class and Candleford the town of the upscale merchant class and local gentry.  Distinctions are made between the residents but they intermingle often to supply much of the light drama.  Most episodes are somewhat self contained, there is an issue or problem which is usually resolved by episodes end while various other plotlines continue throughout the series.  Everything is fairly simplistic, narrated by the young heroine from Lark Rise who moves to Candleford to assist her spinster cousin, the town's Postmistress (a younger Jessica Fletcher type from Murder She Wrote) around whose post office much of the action swirls.
In all its light fare, family friendly, with good acting and some beautiful scenery for those that appreciate their English costume period dramas.

Surprisingly well done period piece pertaining to late 19th century England rural-village and small-town day-to-day life. The surprise comes in the form of the incisive insights the series offers into the culture and social mores of the people in the places and times portrayed. The series only gets better as it progresses, chronicling the life of a young girl, along w/those around her, as she grows to become a self-sufficient young woman in England as the country slowly begins to enter the Industrial Age. Supporting research for series production and presentation is superb. Recommended as well worth the time invested in watching...

Serious but gentle period drama owing much to the charisma and talents of many of the actors, but marred by the overwrought acting of supporting characters. Funny and quirky in turns, it follows the adventures of Laura who has been sent by her parents from the small farming hamlet of Lark Rise to work as postal assistant in the "large" town of Candleford. Much of the drama revolves around the head of the Post Office, Dorcas Lane, and how she meddles in the lives of the townspeople with unpredictable results. Quite addictive

I absolutely loved this series. The acting was brilliant as every character was carved out clearly and made memorable. i could sense an undercurrent of hostility from the writers toward Chrisitans and Christianity. The wisest and kindest of the characters were humanistic, if not, atheistic, while the stupid, narrow minded, and self righteous had an annoying zeal for scripture.  As a Chrisitan myself, it was hurtful to watch biblical principles being portrayed so erroneously. I respect the fact that writers can express their personal views through their work.

I have NEVER seen anything that I loved more! You fall in love with the characters and they truly become your friends! It breaks your heart to have it end! The characters are delightful, the stories are heart felt and the scenery breath taking. It is a sweet show with values, caring, real experiences and interactions that speak to your soul. It had 7 1/2 million viewers when it aired on PBS originally....and people were devastated when they didn't renew the season. That says a lot of what is valued, and needed in our television viewing world of violence, immorality and tasteless performances. You will thoroughly enjoy the experience.

Lark Rise to Candleford is a BBC series set in late 1800s England.  The characters are full of personality and the story lines are wonderful.  Very much along the lines of the Anne of Green Gables series, it will make you laugh and cry.  It is G-rated, which makes this perfect for family viewing. You will become wrapped up in the lives of the people from these two villages.  I have watched Seasons 1-3 and have enjoyed them all immensely!

Instead of capturing your attention with sex, low humor, and over-the-top action, Lark Rise captures you with solid acting, dialogue, and stories that make you feel you're truly living in another place and time (or that you want to).

With all the fuss being made over "Downton Abbey," I was surprised to find that I like this program much, much better. The two shows actually share one cast member. In short, whereas Downton over-glorifies the rich and with token attention to their underlings as underlings, Lark Rise is about real, relatable people and real emotions.

Fall in love with the characters from Lark Rise to Candleford just as you did with the characters of Downton Abbey.  Set in 19th century Oxfordshire it is a tale of love, intrigue, hope and faith.  Told by the viewpoint of Laura Timmons a young girl who moves from the poor farm community of the small hamlet of Candleford to begin an apprenticeship as a post mistress.  Make sure you have plenty of time to sit and indulge because once started you won't want to stop.  Lark Rise to Candleford . . . my one weakness.

Lark Rise is indeed a heart-warming drama. There is much to love about this "Little House on the Prairie", "Waltons"- style show.  The characters are well-developed and superbly acted.  The plot is at times light-hearted but deals with serious issues as well.  Lark Rise is fun, interesting, and family-appropriate for the most part.

What I don't appreciate is that the two characters portrayed as devout Christians are seen as ridiculous, backward, empty-headed, overbearing, spiritual bullies, and in need of modernization in thought and person.  In contrast, the old lady "witch doctor" character with all of her natural remedies, spells, consecration of trees, and practical life advice is hailed as the epitome of wisdom and kindness.  To add to that, Lark Rise seems to be a conservative veil for propagandizing nearly all modern-day liberal causes.

So, on the whole, Lark Rise is a pleasant fifty minutes of decent entertainment if you can stomach the obvious biases and philosophy.

While the series is wonderful clean entertainment, the episode with "Minnie" was disappointing and unrealistic.  Minnie, the new "housekeeper" is not simply carefree, she is lazy, unwilling to take on any work, careless and inconsiderate.  Minnie may not have been raised with much love, but how does that excuse her from being lazy and careless with other people's things and her work responsibility? The things she damaged were invaluable (a mother's wedding dress and a cherished bible) and it doesn't really teach a good lesson to let her stay on.

Lovely British television series about a late 1800's group of friends and relations living in two small country towns.  Each show has a theme and weaves two or three situations around the theme.  For instance, following your dreams was the theme of the episode I watched last night.  We watched how following your dreams affected three people and their families.  There is always a tradeoff between following your dreams and staying with those you love.  Sometimes you can compromise and all be happy.  Sometimes you have to just make the jump.

This is the engaging story of two neighboring communities: the squalid Lark Rise and the comparatively cosmopolitan Candleford, which share a common post office.  The story is set in the late 1890's.  The post office is run by Miss Lane, a wealthy woman in the early years of spinsterhood, who has offered a postal position to young Laura, her cousin's daughter and a Lark Rise native. The stories all involve the people of these two towns and the class distinctions between them, with young Laura struggling to straddle the class divide.

While some of the plots seem a bit hokey and a few of the characters a bit ridiculous (i.e. Thomas the postman) the series is generally well acted (including Brendan Coyle and Samantha Bond of Downtown Abbey fame) and enjoyable to watch.

Definitely a "little house in the English Countryside" type of show, with some plot lines feeling a bit dated, but the cast is uniformly good and doing their best to be sincere (and not campy).  And it's always fun to spot the actors who have become more well known for other work, such as Brendan Coyle, Phil Davis, and even Michelle Fairley.  The 'simpleness' of it means, however, that it's not for all tastes.

We love this series. The character development and the look at life situations without oversimplification is wonderful. Great acting. Great story lines (for the most part, episode 1 season two was strange). It will make a binge viewer out of you.

The actors are excellent; many recognizable from other favorites like "Pride and Prejudice" (the movie) and "Downton Abbey" and the plot lines keep me guessing with twists that surprise and sometimes sadden, but never disappoint. I'm into the second of four seasons now and I still don't know if Dorcas Lane and Laura Timmins will ever get hitched....and maybe that won't be so bad if they never do. I'm still hooked.

If you like stories about Victorian English village life, you will love this series.  Brendan Coyle, Mr. Bates on Downton Abbey, is that same brooding character, but this time he is a starving artisan with a houseful of children in Lark Rise, a poor farming hamlet. His oldest child is Laura who is 17 and works at the post office in nearby Candleford, a charming little prospering village.  Many of the stories surround life at the post office and the post mistress as seen through Laura's eyes.  I'm hooked.
Good wholesome interesting story. Really enjoyed following the characters. I like that new personalities are introduced in different episodes. Funny at times especially Thomas!

Lark Rise to Candleford is a family friendly series that is an interesting study on rich and poor in early English days. It shows that history is indeed cyclic. It is excellent acting, the scenery is exceptional. It is a soft, relaxing, series to watch.
Luv luvv luv this show. It's sweet, sad, and funny. It will make u laugh one minute' and cry the next.

The second season of Lark Rise to Candleford is better than the first because of more complete character development.  The "regulars" continue to develop their character in added dimensions.  Stuff that just seemed quirky in the first season, is now seen to be part of the character's personality.  This aspect is rich.  Not only are we making discoveries, but the characters are learning about one another.  At first glance, the characters may seem too good to be true.  They're not.  As the season unfolds, we discover that these folks are just as challenged as the rest of humans.  Enjoy!
