In the first season, young Laura Timmins (Olivis Hallinan) leaves her village of Lark Rise to work as an assistant to the postmistress in Candleford, Dorcas Lane (Julia Sawalha who was also brilliant in her role as Lydia Bennet in Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E, 1996)). Through the course of the first season, Laura discovers that she enjoys living in the more affluent town of Candleford, and experiences the pangs of adolescence, including romantic entanglements. Dorcas Lane, the kind-hearted and sensible postmistress also goes through some pangs of her own, largely to do with her friendship with squire, Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) who is married to the beautiful and composed Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant). In the first season, viewers got to see the themes of marital strife, conflicts between the upper and lower classes, romantic entanglements, and other issues played out.

By the second season, both Sir Timothy and Lady Adelaide have moved to London, but there is still plenty of drama in Dorcas' life with the arrival of James Dowland (Jason Merrells), a former inhabitant of Lark Rise, a local boy who has done well in life. Being a self-made and wealthy man, James settles in Candleford, though he reacquaints himself with the residents of Lark Rise, especially Queenie Turrill (Linda Bassett) who used to take care of him as a young boy. James opens a fashionable hotel in Candleford, and tries to 'improve' the lives of the Lark Rise residents with mixed results. There is also a strong chemistry between James and Dorcas, though their relationship flounders between attraction and rivalry/conflict. Laura seems more mature and wiser, having learned a couple of enlightening things about the pitfalls of romance, and is taking on more responsibilities at the post office. But then, a young clockmaker, Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty) comes to town, and Laura finds herself attracted to Fisher, though he seems oblivious to her charms, initially. Laura's parents, Robert and Emma Timmins (Brendan Coyle & Claudie Blakley) who have always been a very close and loving couple find themselves facing some marital strife in their marriage, and this second season takes an intimate look at their dynamics as a couple.

There is also plenty of drama amongst the other inhabitants of Lark Rise & Candleford - the sisters Pearl and Ruby Pratt (Matilda Ziegler, Victoria Hamilton) who have a dressmaking/drapery store continue to pry into others' affairs whilst dealing with their own emotional dramas. Postman Thomas Brown's (Mark Heap)romantic (mis)adventures continue, and many more. This is truly a gem of a series, and I am hopelessly addicted to it. Each episode is well-crafted and credibly acted, drawing viewers into the lives of these mostly endearing & flawed characters, and making one feel at home in both Lark Rise and Candleford.

I have enjoyed this series so much and sad that it can't go on forever. Dorcas, Thomas and Margaret seem like old friends. If you love stories about a more innocent time, community, overcoming human frailty and embracing human kindess you will love Lark Rise to Candleford as I do. "It is my one weakness"...

I cannot give enough praise about Lark Rise to Candleford. I love the stories, and I love the characters. The people involved with this series did such a fine job with casting, directing, costumes, scenery, and on and on. The actors they selected were superb for their parts. You must watch this series. I am hooked!

Season one was fantastic. And season two is also wonderful. We do get an odd Dickens-like Christmas ghost story to start the season off with (it was a special episode according to what I read on IMDB). But starting with the second episode, we get to continue the magical story telling that we've come to enjoy from this series.

Season two really focuses on individual character stories. Whereas season one had the incidents or happenings that affected the entire town (Lark Rise or Candleford or both), season two seems to focus on the back story or interactions between one or two characters or families at a time.

Alfie has definitely changed, he is not as whiny as he was in season one. Instead he is portrayed as a coming of age young man who develops a friendship with several of the older men, mainly Twister. We do focus heavily on Ms. Lane and the post office, though Laura is not as prominent a featured character. Instead she is more of the eyewitness to events and her character functions well as a narrator in this regard. Other characters are wonderfully portrayed, and it is with great delight that we view these characters grow and become fond of them.

There are a few characters that do not return from season one for various reasons. Though I do miss them, the new additions are very welcome. The gentleman that owns the new hotel is a particularly complex and enjoyable character to watch. Robert and his family do also feature quite a bit as well.

My question is: what the heck happened to Caroline Arless? Last I saw she was home with the hubby, next thing she's gone and nobody mentions why! The other characters that are not returning had story arcs that ended with the viewers knowing what happened to them.

But I think that season two really builds upon the greatness of season one and exceeds it in several cases. Just power through the haunted episode (which is just for fun) and get to the real heart of season two. Whether Lark Rise is coming together to pave a road or the towns turning out for a hotel opening or parish election; the close knit ties that bind these people together are woven into a wonderful viewing experience. Never are the story arcs too 'dramatic' or involve occurnaces that would have been out of place for the time. This is not a world of villains and sneaks and affairs. This is a world of normal people trying to make their way in rural England in the late 1800s. A world where the arrival of a bicycle causes a ruckus. A world where a woman running for a county office is unheard of. A world where just paying the rent or finding time to read a book can be a trial. It's wonderful television. Bravo!

A second set of 11 episodes (plus a Christmas special) from the BBC's delightful drama series LARK RISE TO CANDLEFORD, based on the autobiographical writings of Flora Thompson.  Quality is pretty much on par with Series 1, but whereas many episodes from the first series had self-contained storylines, the plots in Series 2 tend to continue on; and while most would do this anyway, it's preferable to watch these episodes in numeric order.  As before, the writing is very strong, with lots of depth and nuance injected into the established characters, and some fantastic new faces thrown in the mix.

The four-DVD set kicks off with a special 75-minute Christmas episode, in which the residents of Lark Rise and Candleford are troubled by the presence of a barefoot young woman, with a ragged dressing-gown her only protection from the bitter chill.  The girl stirs up strong feelings from the people whom she meets, including Ruby Pratt (Victoria Hamilton), who finds the courage to stand up to her domineering sister Pearl (Matilda Ziegler); and Caroline (Dawn French), who fears that her husband is preparing to return to the sea.  Laura finds her loyalties torn when she is expected to go back to her family in Lark Rise for Christmas, leaving Dorcas (Julia Sawalha) to spend the festivities alone.

Series 2 officially kicks off with the arrival of James Dowland (Jason Merrells), a former orphan from Lark Rise who has returned to open the Golden Lion Hotel in Candleford - and to no doubt also help usher in a new era of change.  Dorcas and James strike up a competitive relationship as they vie for a position on the local council.  Meanwhile, headaches at the post office are caused by Dorcas' new maid Minnie (Ruby Bentall), a young girl whose flippant attitude to performing her work is matched only by her foolhardy personality - but who also carries a terrifying secret.

Laura is intrigued by Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty), a clockmaker who has been engaged by James to create a clock tower for Candleford, whilst postman Thomas Brown (Mark Heap) woos Margaret Ellison (Sandy McDade) in his own hilarious fashion.  After taking over the care of the latest Timmins baby for a few weeks in order to give exhausted Emma (Claudie Blakley) a small respite from her duties, Dorcas and Ruby both ponder their futures as childless spinsters.  A cruel reversal of fortunes in the Timmins household later threatens to split the family apart altogether when Robert (Brendan Coyle) considers leaving the district to find work.

When Dorcas falls ill with a severe 'flu, it's left to Laura to keep the post office running as smoothly as ever, but with a sleepwalking Thomas and a sudden string of abusive, taunting letters addressed to "The Girl at the Post Office", Laura's new position of authority doesn't come without it's obstacles.  Long-simmering tensions between Lark Rise and its neighbouring hamlet Fordlow run riot when Alf (John Dagleish) starts courting Nan Carter (Rebecca Night).  James' past, in the form of a beautiful older woman (Samantha Bond), comes back to haunt him; and in the days leading up to Thomas and Margaret's wedding, James and Dorcas once again find themselves at odds, this time concerning the welfare of a bespectacled, ten-year-old boy named Sydney...

If you loved the first round of episodes, you'll adore these.

This is a great show, and I am never disappointed when I see this. All the episodes are wonderfully acted and the film quality is exceptional! It is a great show to watch on those rainy days or just when you want to see an all-around easy to watch show. Plenty but not too much of romance, conflict, and lessons to be learned. I highly recommend it with 5 stars.

I bought season two and three in blu-ray and tried to play in my Sony BDP-S360 but they would not. I updated the firmware and still no luck. I went to Best Buy today (8 January 2012) and took Season 2 along and tried the newest Sony 3D blu-ray BDPBX58 and they still wouldn't play. The salesman and I then tried the LG BD670 and the discs played perfectly! I bought the player, took it home, and we just watched an episode and some extras and all went beautifully.
Now for the series: we were introduced to Lark Rise by our Australian friends (she is originally from the UK) and we were hooked after the first episode. To make you appreciate where we're coming from, I have to tell you the following background information: we have a gigantic video collection with all kinds of classic films and TV series. We have five boys and a girl ranging from seven to 22 years and we've always watched everything as a family, and before Lark Rise we would have told you that some of our favorite movie and tv productions were Lord of the Rings, Amadeus, the original Twilight Zone, classic Star Trek, Alfred Hitchcock movies, etc. We are all in complete agreement that Lark Rise is the most riveting, well-written, best-cast series ever shown on television. The acting is superb - just flawless - and you feel as if you're living with the characters as they draw out every emotion from you.  Unlike Little House on the Prairie, which was so predictable that you could map out each episode about a minute after it started, the Lark Rise writers have you literally sitting on the edge of your seat in anticipation (and worry) of what will happen next. We've been taken by complete surprise about a dozen times already.  We are all dreading the end of season four as we wish that this series would have went on forever.

Lark Rise to Candleford is a charming series that tackles myriad themes, and is adapted from Flora Thompson's semi-autobiographical novel. In the first season, young Laura Timmins (Olivis Hallinan) leaves her village of Lark Rise to work as an assistant to the postmistress in Candleford, Dorcas Lane (Julia Sawalha who was also brilliant in her role as Lydia Bennet in the 1996 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice). Through the course of the first season, Laura discovers that she enjoys living in the more affluent town of Candleford, and experiences the pangs of adolescence, including romantic entanglements. Dorcas Lane, the kind-hearted and sensible postmistress also goes through some pangs of her own, largely to do with her friendship with squire, Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) who is married to the beautiful and composed Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant). In the first season, viewers got to see the themes of marital strife, conflicts between the upper and lower classes, romantic entanglements, and other issues played out.

By the second season, both Sir Timothy and Lady Adelaide have moved to London, but there is still plenty of drama in Dorcas' life with the arrival of James Dowland (Jason Merrells), a former inhabitant of Lark Rise, a local boy who has done well in life. Being a self-made and wealthy man, James settles in Candleford, though he reacquaints himself with the residents of Lark Rise, especially Queenie Turrill (Linda Bassett) who used to take care of him as a young boy. James opens a fashionable hotel in Candleford, and tries to 'improve' the lives of the Lark Rise residents with mixed results. There is also a strong chemistry between James and Dorcas, though their relationship flounders between attraction and rivalry/conflict. Laura seems more mature and wiser, having learned a couple of enlightening things about the pitfalls of romance, and is taking on more responsibilities at the post office. But then, a young clockmaker, Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty) comes to town, and Laura finds herself attracted to Fisher, though he initially seems oblivious to her charms. Laura's parents, Robert and Emma Timmins (Brendan Coyle & Claudie Blakley) who have always been a very close and loving couple find themselves facing some marital strife in their marriage, and this second season takes an intimate look at their dynamics as a couple.

There is also plenty of drama amongst the other inhabitants of Lark Rise & Candleford - the sisters Pearl and Ruby Pratt (Matilda Ziegler, Victoria Hamilton) who have a dressmaking/drapery store continue to pry into others' affairs whilst dealing with their own emotional dramas. Postman Thomas Brown's (Mark Heap)romantic (mis)adventures continue, and many more. This is truly a wonderful period drama. Each episode is well-crafted and credibly acted, drawing viewers into the lives of these mostly endearing & flawed characters, and making one feel at home in both Lark Rise and Candleford.

LOVED this series. Beautiful character development....entertaining but not trashy.
I felt perfectly comfortable watching this with my seven year old daughter. Great purchase!

This is such a wonderful, family-friendly series that I would recommend to anyone!  My husband and I both loved it and I've loaned my sets out to friends also.  I just wish there were more seasons out there!

We are getting ready to wrap up season 2 of Lark Rise to Candleford. I have to say that this is one of the most well done series I have ever seen. The casting of the characters is excellent. My husband who loves his action movies has watched these with me faithfully and has admitted he actually enjoys the episodes.
It is so hard these days to find material that is acted and produced well without the unnecessary explicit sex scenes and language. I look forward to season 3.
Lark Rise is a brilliant series and thoroughly enjoyable.  Fine acting at it's best.  I love the humour too.  Dorcas Lane has so many weaknesses.  Entertaining and delightful to watch time and again.

Our whole family enjoys this British series about two small communities and the people  who live there.  Careful....you'll get hooked.

Excellent.  A great deal of wisdom in each persons' talking to each other
this is true of all 4 season.  highly recommended

Lark Rise to Candleford: The Complete Season One is a charming series that tackles myriad themes, and is adapted from Flora Thompson's semi-autobiographical novel. In the first season, young Laura Timmins (Olivis Hallinan) leaves her village of Lark Rise to work as an assistant to the postmistress in Candleford, Dorcas Lane (Julia Sawalha who was also brilliant in her role as Lydia Bennet in Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E, 1996)). Through the course of the first season, Laura discovers that she enjoys living in the more affluent town of Candleford, and experiences the pangs of adolescence, including romantic entanglements. Dorcas Lane, the kind-hearted and sensible postmistress also goes through some pangs of her own, largely to do with her friendship with squire, Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) who is married to the beautiful and composed Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant). In the first season, viewers got to see the themes of marital strife, conflicts between the upper and lower classes, romantic entanglements, and other issues played out.

By the second season, both Sir Timothy and Lady Adelaide have moved to London, but there is still plenty of drama in Dorcas' life with the arrival of James Dowland (Jason Merrells), a former inhabitant of Lark Rise, a local boy who has done well in life. Being a self-made and wealthy man, James settles in Candleford, though he reacquaints himself with the residents of Lark Rise, especially Queenie Turrill (Linda Bassett) who used to take care of him as a young boy. James opens a fashionable hotel in Candleford, and tries to 'improve' the lives of the Lark Rise residents with mixed results. There is also a strong chemistry between James and Dorcas, though their relationship flounders between attraction and rivalry/conflict. Laura seems more mature and wiser, having learned a couple of enlightening things about the pitfalls of romance, and is taking on more responsibilities at the post office. But then, a young clockmaker, Fisher Bloom (Matthew McNulty) comes to town, and Laura finds herself attracted to Fisher, though he seems oblivious to her charms, initially. Laura's parents, Robert and Emma Timmins (Brendan Coyle & Claudie Blakley) who have always been a very close and loving couple find themselves facing some marital strife in their marriage, and this second season takes an intimate look at their dynamics as a couple.

There is also plenty of drama amongst the other inhabitants of Lark Rise & Candleford - the sisters Pearl and Ruby Pratt (Matilda Ziegler, Victoria Hamilton) who have a dressmaking/drapery store continue to pry into others' affairs whilst dealing with their own emotional dramas. Postman Thomas Brown's (Mark Heap)romantic (mis)adventures continue, and many more. This is truly a gem of a series, and I am hopelessly addicted to it. Each episode is well-crafted and credibly acted, drawing viewers into the lives of these mostly endearing & flawed characters, and making one feel at home in both Lark Rise and Candleford.
I love the series, and I hope they start it back up!! I will be sad to see the last one.
Started watching this series in season 3 - had to get the series 1 and 2 - great to watch!

As I expressed in my review of season one (1) of this series, "Lark Rise to Candleford" gives me some respite from my usual viewing of the murder/mystery/detective genre that I really adore.  Season two (2) on four (4) discs again presents gentle non-violent stories about a bunch of very amiable folks that live in the very beautiful, picturesque and idealist villages of Lark Rise and Candleford in the early 1800s.  Through the eyes of Laura Timmins we get to view some gentle happenings to some intriguing country folks in Larks Rise and to some more "citified" folks in Candleford through the "happenings" at the post office.  These "happenings" involve class prejudices, love, family loyalties, jealousies, ghosts, problems of growing up along with the problems of growing old, stewardship, the work ethic, etc.  All of the stories in this season two (2) are so well told without any violence or mayhem that one is able to just sit-back and get involved in the lives of some nice people.

The great presentation of the first season continues with season two. Ideal for the whole family to watch with no nasty surprises.

The writing, acting and casting are excellent.
If you like British series, this one is a keeper.  Once you start watching Lark Rise to Candleford, you are hooked.  Series 2 was totally entertaining.

This is a wonderful series.  Have purchased the whole entire season.  Just great entertainment.  Wondering what we're going to do after we finish watching season 4 - will have withdrawal symptoms for sure!

The second season is as good as the first. No one does period programs as well as BBC. Everything on the set seems authentic for the time period from buildings, costumes, and everything the people use in their daily lives. The acting is top-notch, you become immersed in the lives of the people both from the humble village of Larkrise and the modest town of Candleford. You learn alot about relationships between people from this series. Even my husband loves them!

EXCELLENT PERIOD PIECE - I watch many, many period piece movies and series. I see excellent costumes true to their period. Also, I look for furniture, decoration on room walls, outside grounds, clarity of voice and brightness of coloring, not just how the characters play their parts. I only give 5 stars when a movie or series passes all the tests, and I feel this one deserves a 5. Worth buying on Blu-ray.
I enjoyed the Christmas episode so much that I want to watch it every year at holiday time. My review for Season 3 also applies to Season 2.

Lark Rise to Candleford is based on a set of books written in later life by the main character, Laura.  We have seen three seasons in the Series and enjoy them very much.  It is great family entertainment for children 12 and older.  I'm afraid that smaller children will spend too much of viewer's time and attention asking questions.  However, there is little or no foul language (and it's mild at that) and very little nudity outside of that one might catch a glimpse of in the routine of living in rural 19th Century England.  My wife thoroughly enjoy the great story, the many well developed characters, and the truely professional presentation.  One is transported mentally, as an observer, to a very interesting and, in some ways, fun and much less hectic life of an English country village, Lark Rise, and it supporting country town, Candleford.  It is life, with all its ups and downs, as it must have been in the Victorian countryside.

I had to get season 2, after becoming utterly hooked on season 1. These characters,settings, stories......they are so rich,and marvelously executed. This is quality programming,for sure. BBC sure knows how to produce top-notch series,that leave you hungering for more. I, like others, was a bit mystified by episode 1,involving the "ghost".This story would have been good on its own.....a young girl,searching for her Pa,folks trying to help....yet the fact that there was a supernatural basis to it left me disappointed. I DID like it, just wish the storyline was different. The new maid,Minnie,is a fabulous addition,that will have you laughing out loud at times, at her "antics". There are new and old characters that will continue/begin to melt your heart. I do miss Sir Timothy, and Lady Adelaide,but am grateful the Pratt sisters are back. They are like the Baldwin sisters,of the Waltons series, from the 70's. Highly amusing. I feel like I am "friends" with these people...I so wish I could sit and relax over tea with Dorcas,or spend an afternoon at Queenie and Twister's. I am almost through with season 3,and axiously await season 4. Thank you BBC.This is shaping up to be a memorable series.

absolutely wonderful and entertaining, I enjoyed it so much I immediately wanted to buy the actual book and learn more about it. I bought all the avalible seasons of it and hope somehow someway they continue to make more like it. They had actors from other famous and well known bbc series like north and south, pride and prejudice... it was amazing to see how some actors have aged and others make you yearn for actors like them in the United States that it is more about art and craft not $$$ dollar signs and press

Don't be fooled into thinking that this is just another English Period Piece.
The book(that this series is based on) might have been written describing the late 19th century Oxford shire England but the problems encountered by the characters are truly 21th Century problems.
I was hooked after the 1st Episode of Series One.
Series 2 and 3 are even better. I am awaiting the arrival of Series 4 on DVD.
Acting,Locations,Costumes are all superb.
You'll love it!
this saga is Excellent!!  I hope it continues for a long time. Each episode is a good story and so enjoyable.  I highly recommended this movie.

This series is extremely well done and captures the heart of small village life at the turn of the 20th century.  The characters are well developed and each episode comprises many aspects of daily life.

My family is hooked on the Lark Rise to Candelford series.  It is such an uplifting break from what is normally available in the media.  I don't have to worry about offensive language, inappropriate subject matter, and morals still rule in this series.
Purchased this as a gift for my wife who is a Jane Austen, English lore fan who says Lark Rise to Candleford is the English version of Little House on Prairie . . . great family programming.

While the setting is an old charming village, the situations confronting individuals and families are timeless. Strong values triumph over moral issues after thoughtful struggles, often handled with great sensitivity by the characters (a courtesy for others that seems to be lacking in modern times). The stories have application for today's challenges, and lessons can be learned.  The acting is excellent, and there are interesting twists and turns. The series exceeds my expectations.

I have purchased all 3 seasons of Lark Rise to Candleford and have enjoyed them immensely.  This is a story of Laura Timmons and her life after she moves to Candleford to live with her mother's cousin Dorcas Lane.  I watched this series with my daughter over a period of 2 months and we so thoroughly enjoyed them.  It was funny and witty.  It was so totally engaging.  In fact, I began to identify the actions of a few of the characters with people that I know.  And wow, not one uncomfortable moment.  Definitely a family movie.  I can not wait until the 4th season is released.

This is a great family show with all kinds of drama and good clean fun. There are occasional times when I don't like how they handle things and I wish it didn't have a bunch of superstition, but other than that I really love the show.
I love, love, love this show!!!!  I cannot say one bad word about Larkrise.  It's a show I always look forward to watching.  Buy it-you won't regret it!

My wife, 11-year old daughter, mother-in-law, and I are hooked on BBC's "Lark Rise to Candleford" TV series.  During season 1 we got to know the characters that live in the out village of Lark Rise, as well as the prominent citizens of the larger market town, Candleford.  The setting stays the same in season 2, where we get to follow the lives of our friends from season 1 as they continue to toil and make their way in rural 1895 England.

This is outstanding family entertainment, with something for everyone, though it will probably not hold the attention of the children in grades 1-3 or so in elementary school.  It, frankly, doesn't sell too well with my HS son either.  Regardless, this is a great series, and if you haven't yet tried it, I heartily encourage you to do so.

This show is entirely watchable.  There has been nothing in the first two seasons that I have been hesistant about either my 11-year old daughter or mother-in-law seeing.  Get the picture?  Though I have to admit that episode 1 in season 2 was a bit freaky, with everyone seeing the ghost(?) of a girl, and then trying to figure out what that means.  Anyway, the people were still clearly largely superstitious, and comes across here and there.

The stories are engaging, and the acting is top-notch.  I like the characters, the setting of the story, and the way you get to know the characters in this series.

5 stars all the way!

SPOILER REVIEW The Christmas Special (which is the first segment in season 2) left me VERY concerned. Nothing captures the spirit of the holidays like... a ghost? No idea what on earth they were thinking with this one but I won't watch that again. Gratefully, the season did perk up from there a bit, but DEFINITELY not at the same level as Lark Rise to Candleford: The Complete Season One. I'd liken it to Cranford: Return to Cranford in comparison with Cranford - in other words the cheesy factor definitely went up, but it's still an enjoyable watch if you've grown attached to the series. --------------------- I'm adding this to my review after having watched the series again. On second watching I found that aside from the Christmas Special (which did have one piece of main plot line in that Alf's dad decides to stay with his family rather than go back to sea), only the last 2 episodes really started to fall off quality-wise. So I increased the number of stars I gave from a 4 to a 5.

This slow-moving series is addictive; the characters are all so cute.  You care about them, so you WANT to know what happens to them.  My only beef is that near the end of this series, it started to feel like a paranormal soap opera.  I mean, what's with the premonitions?  And the drama, oh, the DRAMA!  Parts of this are definitely soap opera material.  Still, it's enjoyable.......if a bit......SLLLLOOOOOOOOOWWWWWWWWWWWWWW.

I cannot express strongly enough intense dissatisfaction regarding poor policies re Amazon's distribution and/or those of allied companies that have duped consumers by mailing out defective DVDs in the Blueray format with "BD50" format without warning that they DO NOT work on Sony Blue Ray player and Panasonic (new 3D player) and perhaps other players that do not support the BD50.  This involves the consumer having to repackage and return the items without the enjoyment of viewing the media - I tried even in my personal computer DVD drive to no avail.  Very bad PR - they ought to be ashamed of themselves!  Richard Beaudry

This is a delightful, affectionate, humorous, but not sugar-coated look at life in the rural community of Lark Rise and the market town of Candleford just before the 20th century.  It is told through the eyes of young Laura, about 16, who has been sent from Lark Rise to work in the post office in Candleford.  The trials and tribulations of several village families are told with compassion and wit.  Characters like Mrs. Arlis and her brood of children, Queenie and Twister, the older couple, and the sparkling independent postmistress Dorcas Lane are well drawn and you the viewer are drawn into their lives.

I really enjoy watching this series. My husband doesn't like them and will only watch when he wants to impress me. I pass them on to friends and their husbands do like them. I am currently watching season 3 and it is very wonderful also.

This delightful series is a well written parallel to our "Little House on the Prairie" - with more seasoned actors and a better look into the hamlet/city culture of the England that my parents came from.  The characters - without exception - are so well defined, with such human virtues and flaws and the stories so believeble - not one nasty word, how very refreshing - especially for the British!

At first, I had no idea what I'd ordered, but after the first few episodes (Season One), I was completely absorbed in the series.  Season Two added more period drama and amusement, and it is a joy to watch.  I have pre-ordered Seaon Three, and am looking so forward to the continuing saga of the folks at Lark Rise and Candleford.
This series has truly become my "one weakness."  It is sure not to disappoint!  I always walk away feeling good for having watched it.

I purchased all three series of Larkrise to Candleford - the third one last year already. My husband and I are in our 80's and we have watched all three over and over again (along with Cranford and Return to Cranford and several other period DVD's. The third series is just as good as the other two and I would recommend it heartily.
Una

I add another 5-star review to the Lark Rise series' string. These well-crafted episodes based on Flora Thompson's book present an interesting mix of interpersonal relationships and the impact of changes and social issues in town and village on their residents. But another aspect of these discs' content earns an unfavorable review -- the frustrating user experience with the BBC introductory material and the menu. It is impossible to play the episodes in Set 2 one at a time (stopping the DVD between episodes) without having to sit through the front-end commercials and annoyingly prolonged copyright warning on every occasion. These discs do not allow the viewer to fast-forward through or skip this material --or at least I haven't yet found a way. I remember the episode selection menu in Set 1 being much more straightforward and user-friendly. I look forward to watching the episodes in Set 3, but hope those discs do not share the introduction and menu problems of Set 2.

The setting for the series was excellant and good actors, however I was disappointed by the stories-- too unreal and bordered on mystic. Also I found some of the relationships between the characters frustating. If I had it to buy over again I wouldn't. But still I do like the actors and I did like the first season one series.

Overall I enjoyed the second season of this series. But I thought the Christmas episode was hokey. I also feel that the addition of certain characters, such as an illegitimate son of Dowland (?) shows a certain desperation in trying to keep the series going.

Season two did not disappoint in any way---it was as entertaining as season one.  I enjoyed both of them immensely and look forward to season three.  I understand this series was very popular and well received in the UK and I'm sure season three will follow.......I look forward to it.

My husband & I are addicted to this series.  We've seen season 1 and couldn't wait to buy season 2.  These are clean, uplifting and the acting is outstanding.  We watch an episode every few nights as a reward at the end of a long day.

My husband and I just love this series!  It is clean, witty entertainment that leaves you feeling good.  It is so refreshing to watch compared with so many other movies and shows these days that leave you feeling like you have just wasted your time.

Some heavy weight British talent on this series I had hoped for a bit more depth. Too much of a "Feel Good" series. Not a bad show but a combination of Jane Austen meets Laura Ingalls Wilder with
a touch of Father Murphy and Doctor Quinn added.
Actress Claudie Blakley, daughter of musician Alan Blakley, has one of the lead roles and she's wasting her talent on what is not much more than a "soap" in period costume.
Season One was just too predictable and the best episode was one in which the fine British actor, Phil Davis guested.

Not bad for light weight entertainment just don't expect shades of Dickens or Austen.

Well done series making you excited about season 3. My mom is British and really enjoys theses pieces about old England, small villages and the like. We have a mom daughter get together to watch this series and do lunch. I recently discovered season 3 had been on KPBS. Can't wait till season 3 available.

I stumbled across the first season of Lark Rise to Candleford while hunting something else and discovered one of the most amazing and enjoyable series, I've seen. I was delighted to find a second season and would love to see a third season. It is easy to forget the actors are acting. The attention to detail makes the setting so real it would be easy to go there.  The change coming upon rural England, the daily lives, the courage, humor, joys, and sorrows come to life in these beautiful episodes and amazing characters. This is in the finest tradition of BBC period pieces, The Pallisers, the Jane Austen novels, and Elizabeth Gaskill.

There is something about this series that is so wonderful to watch. Is it a time gone by, when people took their time to do and see others in their lives? Poor people who are happy just being together, something you can not buy. Yes i believe i've become addicted to watching this and will await for the 3rd series to be released. I enjoy all the characters at Lark Rise and candleford equally.
I recommend viewing this series.

I love what the writers have done to the books by Flora Thompson!  They have created characters to inhabit the county that Flora described.  Almost all of the people are either new or if named in the books, they have been given different personas.  The storylines have been wonderful, full of twists and turns and thoughly enjoyable.  I recommend watching the series on DVD.
I can't wait until Season 3 - does anyone know when it will be here???

My wife and I recently performed a general evaluation of all the movies or television shows we've watched in our 4 years together, and it is our feeling that the Lark Rise to Candleford series has given us about half of our favorite "movie moments," as we like to call them. We cherish our late-night opportunities to catch an episode and relish some of the best acting modern film has to offer (Twister is masterfully acted). If you LOVE some of the incredible moments delivered by Pride & Pejudice (Ehle, Firth) or the latest Sense & Sensibility, or some of the character driven intricacies of plot from Anne of Green Gables and Cranford, you will LOVE Lark Rise to Candleford. Buy seasons 1 & 2 for yourself today, or if you want, you can borrow ours. Everybody else is!!!

As I said in the title, it is an entertaining, engaging, well-acted period drama. We are partial to shows of this type (the kind of thing that you would see on Masterpiece theatre) especially British productions. The characters are likable, the acting is good and the scenery is appealing. Despite being set in the late Victorian period in rural Oxfordshire, much of the heart of the experiences and emotions of the characters are still relevant and you are always left wanting to know what will happen next. I like the fact that the cast aren't all "big names" and familiar faces(except perhaps for Julia Sawalha whom I enjoy watching anyway).

It's also an interesting study of the era and a "place" that no longer exists - as were the books on which the series was based.

The Christmas special episode was a bit naff and out of character for the overall series, so don't let that put you off (but then again Christmas episodes often are a disappointment).

Looking forward to Series 3 being released next year.

My entire family loves this series from BBC.  It reminds me of a much more sophisticated Little House on the Prairie. In fact, the more I think about it, it has a lot in common with that series.  We would recommend this to anyone.  In fact, my wife won't even lend it out because she is watching it again.

Lark Rise to Candleford: The Complete Season Two is wonderful.  Most of the familiar, lovable characters from season one return.  The season two series does, however, suffer a problem season one suffered -- it ends far too soon.  LRTC proves that quality entertainment can be achieved without resulting to the vulgar, mundane, or tasteless.  You laugh, you cry, you become totally wrapped up in each of the characters from Lark Rise and Chandleford. It's Victorian with a flair for real-life relationships that are as true today as in the 1800's.  No detail is left undone: scenery, props, costumes, characterizations.  I can hardly wait for season three to make it to DVD.

This product was delivered in a very timely manner and in excellent condition.  I'm saving it to view when I'm with my daughter in June.  I hope the discs are in good condition.  Everything looks good though.
it was great

Many, many of the episodes presented here on Amazon Prime are missing relevant scenes that appeared in the original PBS telecasts. To name just one example: at least THREE SCENES are missing from a single episode, Season 2, Episode 5: A scene in which Alf and Robert Timmins sit in a pub discussing Minnie's claim of "being ruined," a scene in which Robert Timmins offers James Dowland some of his personal advice on courting Dorcas Lane, and a third scene in which Emma Timmins talks to Robert about their son's having made a map. I have found many disappointing omissions on other episodes in the series presented here as well, as anyone who has seen the original PBS telecasts will attest. WHAT'S GOING ON, AMAZON? There is no reason to shorten the episodes here. I'm sure there must be a profit motive involved somewhere, but it's not in the best interests of the viewers here. I have also noticed missing scenes from other series presented here, such as NYPD Blue.

This is just a delightful show that I am thoroughly enjoying.  I limit myself to one episode per day, and sometimes it is a challenge to not watch another.  It is something I look forward to all day.  Very sweet stories with very wise characters.  Good even for children or pre-teens and teens to watch.
